name: Backend Code Quality Rubric
description: Evaluates backend code quality across correctness, style, performance, and documentation dimensions.

criteria.name: Correctness
criteria.description: Code implements requirements correctly, handles edge cases, and has no bugs.

levels.0-2 (Poor): Multiple bugs, missing requirements, incorrect logic
levels.3-5 (Acceptable): Core requirements met, some edge cases missing
levels.6-7 (Good): All requirements met, most edge cases handled
levels.8-10 (Excellent): All requirements met, comprehensive edge case handling, robust error management

examples.poor: Missing input validation, SQL injection vulnerabilities
examples.good: Comprehensive validation, parameterized queries, proper error codes

criteria.name: Code Style
criteria.description: Code follows language conventions, is readable, and maintainable.

levels.0-2 (Poor): Inconsistent style, poor naming, spaghetti code
levels.6-7 (Good): Consistent style, clear naming, logical structure
levels.8-10 (Excellent): Exemplary style, self-documenting code, excellent separation of concerns

examples.poor: Single-letter variables, 200-line functions, no error handling
examples.good: Clear variable names, functions <50 lines, proper abstractions

criteria.name: Performance
criteria.description: Code is efficient, scalable, and optimized for the problem domain.

levels.0-2 (Poor): Obvious performance issues, N+1 queries, memory leaks
levels.6-7 (Good): Optimized algorithms, proper indexing, caching where needed
levels.8-10 (Excellent): Highly optimized, scalable design, comprehensive performance testing

examples.poor: O(nÂ²) where O(n) possible, missing database indexes
examples.good: O(n log n) algorithms, indexed queries, connection pooling

criteria.name: Documentation
criteria.description: Code is well-documented with clear API docs, README, and comments where needed.

levels.0-2 (Poor): No documentation, missing README, uncommented complex logic
levels.3-5 (Acceptable): Basic README, some comments, minimal API docs
levels.6-7 (Good): Comprehensive README, API docs, comments for complex logic
levels.8-10 (Excellent): Complete documentation, API examples, architecture diagrams, setup guides

examples.poor: No README, no docstrings, magic numbers without explanation
examples.good: README with setup, OpenAPI spec, docstrings on all public functions
